properties.name: Community Information
properties.location: Gundowring, Kergunyah South, Sandy Creek, Upper Gundowring
properties.webBody:
This Community Information is being issued for Gundowring, Kergunyah South, Sandy Creek, Upper Gundowring.

  • There is a grassfire at Began Lane, Gundowring that is under control. 
  • Smoke may be visible from nearby communities and roads for two days. 
  • Firefighters are responding to this fire. 
There is no immediate threat to the community and no action is required.
This message was issued by Country Fire Authority.

Unless the situation changes, this will be the last message issued for this fire

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au.
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.
  • VicEmergency app.
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires).
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility:
The following service can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Services on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
properties.text:
COMMUNITY INFORMATION - GRASS FIRE - Stay Informed
Incident Location: Began Lane, Gundowring
Issue Date: Monday 06 May 2024, 09:44 am
Next Update: Wednesday 08 May 2024, 06:00 pm

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/33571/moreinfo

This Community Information is being issued for Gundowring, Kergunyah South, Sandy Creek, Upper Gundowring.

- There is a grassfire at Began Lane, Gundowring that is under control. 
- Smoke may be visible from nearby communities and roads for two days. 
- Firefighters are responding to this fire. 


There is no immediate threat to the community and no action is required.

properties.name: Community Information
properties.webBody:
This message is being issued for water quality at Lake Bolac

  •  High levels of blue-green algae have been detected in the lake.
  •  The algal bloom is expected to remain until there is significant rainfall to flush the lake or cooler conditions slow the algae.
  •  Regular testing is being conducted to identify new outbreaks or changes that might indicate improved water quality. 
  • This notification will be reviewed weekly and updated as the situation changes. 
Warning signs have been installed at the lake. 

You should avoid direct contact with the affected water in Lake Bolac.

Do not swim in affected areas or use water for cooking, drinking, washing, or showering. Boiling the water will not make it safe.
What you should do:
  • Visit Parks Victoria website  (https://www.parks.vic.gov.au/places-to-see/parks/lake-bolac-highway-park) for more information.
  • Observe information signs posted at the lake.

Protect your health:
  • Direct contact with water affected by blue green algae can cause skin irritation, sore eyes, ears and nose. If swallowed it can cause cramps, nausea and vomiting. 
  • If you do come into contact with affected water, wash your skin immediately in clean cool water. 
  • Boiling affected water does not make it safe to drink. Boiling water bursts the blue green algae cells and releases toxins into the water making it more likely that you will experience symptoms. 
  • If you are experiencing any health issues after contact with affected water seek medical advice from your local doctor or Nurse-On-Call on 1300 60 60 24.

Protect your pets:
  • Pet owners should prevent pets from drinking or having direct contact with contaminated water. 
Agriculture information: 
  • Irrigation water contaminated with blue-green algae should not be spray irrigated on vegetables and fruit, or come in contact with plants being grown for food during processing and packing. 
  • Fruit and vegetables grown in the affected areas are safe to consume if farmers follow recommendations regarding blue-green algae.
Impacts in your area:
  • The water is green as a result of the algae bloom.

Boating and fishing:
  • Boating and fishing is still allowed in these areas, however, care needs to be taken.
  • Fish caught from affected areas should be rinsed and cleaned thoroughly in fresh water, and internal organs removed from the fish and discarded before eating. 
  • Do not eat mussels, crayfish, or yabbies caught from the affected area. 
This message was issued by Department of Energy, Environment and Climate Action.

The next update is expected by 31/05/2024 03:30 pm or as the situation changes.

Information about blue green algae:
  • For information on blue green algae visit: www2.health.vic.gov.au/public-health/water/blue-green-algae-cyanobac teria.
Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au.
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.
  • VicEmergency app.
  • Facebook or Twitter.
  • Tune into ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
properties.text:
COMMUNITY INFORMATION - BLUE GREEN ALGAE - Stay Informed
Incident Location: Lake Bolac
Issue Date: Monday 29 April 2024, 03:28 pm
Next Update: Friday 31 May 2024, 03:30 pm

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/33547/moreinfo

This message is being issued for water quality at Lake Bolac
-  High levels of blue-green algae have been detected in the lake.
-  The algal bloom is expected to remain until there is significant rainfall to flush the lake or cooler conditions slow the algae.
-  Regular testing is being conducted to identify new outbreaks or changes that might indicate improved water quality. 
- This notification will be reviewed weekly and updated as the situation changes. 



Warning signs have been installed at the lake. 

You should avoid direct contact with the affected water in Lake Bolac.

Do not swim in affected areas or use water for cooking, drinking, washing, or showering. Boiling the water will not make it safe.

properties.name: Advice
properties.location: Coral Bank, Mongans Bridge, Kancoona, Running Creek
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for Coral Bank, Kancoona, Mongans Bridge, Running Creek.

  • There is a bushfire at 12.5Km North West Of Tawonga that is under control.
  • This Advice replaces the Advice issued at 4:28 PM on Friday 3 May.
There is currently no threat to communities, but you should continue to stay informed and monitor conditions.
What you should do: 
  • Monitor weather conditions and warnings. 
  • Review your fire survival plan. 
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes.
  • Keep the roads clear so emergency services can respond.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Firefighters are responding to this fire.
  • Smoke may be visible to nearby communities and roads.
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 10:00 am, 06 May 2024 or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for Allans Flat, Kergunyah.

  • There is a bushfire at Jarvis Lane, Kergunyah that is not yet under control.
There is currently no threat to communities, but you should continue to stay informed and monitor conditions.
What you should do: 
  • Monitor weather conditions and warnings. 
  • Review your fire survival plan. 
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Emergency services will remain in the area.
  • Smoke may be visible from nearby communities and roads. 
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 07/05/2024 10:00 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:

  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice

  • There is a bushfire next to Meurant Lane, 10km south of Yackandandah that is not yet under control.
  • There is currently no threat to communities, but you should continue to stay informed and monitor conditions.
What you should do: 
  • Monitor weather conditions and warnings. 
  • Review your fire survival plan.

properties.name: Community Information
properties.webBody:
This Community Information message is being issued for Bright and surrounds. 

  • You will see or smell smoke across Bright, and to the north of Bright.
  • Smoke is the result of burning from multiple sources including private property burn offs and planned burns on public land.
  • Two bushfires in the area are contributing to the smoke, along with smoke from fireplaces and wood stoves.  
  • It is expected that smoke impacts will continue for at least the next 24 hours. 
  • The smoke is expected to clear late morning each day, before returning later in the evening. 
  • Go to EPA AirWatch for further details epa.vic.gov.au/airwatch
  • This Community Information replaces the Community Information issued at 2:07 pm on Sunday 5 May. 
There is no immediate threat to the community and no action is required.
What you should do: 
  • If you can see or smell smoke, take the necessary precautions to protect your health. You can self-assess the air quality near you using: https://www.epa.vic.gov.au/for-community/environmental-information/air-quality/smoke/smoke-your-health. 
  • Stay up-to-date with current air quality information, forecasts in your area, and advice at epa.vic.gov.au/airwatch.
Take action to reduce your exposure to smoke and protect your health:
  • People over 65 years, children 14 years and younger, pregnant women and those with existing heart or lung conditions, should reduce prolonged or heavy physical activity.
  • Where possible (and not under direct threat from fires), limit the time spent outdoors.
  • When indoors, close windows and doors.
  •  If there is a break in smoky conditions, open the windows and air out your home.
  • Use a portable air cleaner with a HEPA filter if you have access to one. 
  • Use a P2 or N95 mask when outdoors. If you have a pre-existing heart or lung condition, seek advice from your doctor if you experience difficulty breathing while wearing a mask. 
  • Go to a place with cleaner air (such as an air-conditioned building like a library or shopping centre, or the house of family and friends) if it is safe to do so. 
  • Follow the treatment plan recommended by your doctor. If you or anyone in your care has trouble breathing or tightness in the chest, call Triple Zero 000 for an ambulance. 
  • Signs of short-term smoke irritation such as eye, nose and throat irritation and coughing usually clear up in healthy adults once away from the smoke.   
  • People with a heart or lung condition, people with diabetes, pregnant women, infants and children are more sensitive to adverse health effects associated with smoke exposure.
  • If you are concerned about your symptoms seek medical advice or call Nurse-on-Call on 1300 60 60 24.
Preparing for smoke events:
  • Prepare your home before a smoke event by identifying any gaps and sealing these where possible. If sealing gaps is not possible, wet towels can be used to cover gaps when there is smoke outside. 
  • Switch air-conditioners to recirculate or reuse air. If you cannot, turn the air-conditioner off.  
  • Ensure you always have at least five daysâ€™ supply of medication on hand. If you or a family member has a heart or lung condition, including asthma, always make sure there is enough medication. 
  • Find out if indoor air cleaners or face masks are appropriate for you and your family.
This message was issued by Environment Protection Authority. 

This will be the final message issued for this incident. 

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires) 
  • ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV. 
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
properties.text: COMMUNITY INFORMATION - AIR QUALITY - Stay Informed Incident Location: Bright and surrounds Issue Date: Monday 06 May 2024, 02:23 pm Next Update: Tuesday 07 May 2024, 02:00 pm More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/33576/moreinfo This Community Information message is being issued for Bright and surrounds. - You will see or smell smoke across Bright, and to the north of Bright. - Smoke is the result of burning from multiple sources including private property burn offs and planned burns on public land. - Two bushfires in the area are contributing to the smoke, along with smoke from fireplaces and wood stoves. - It is expected that smoke impacts will continue for at least the next 24 hours. - The smoke is expected to clear late morning each day, before returning later in the evening. - Go to EPA AirWatch for further details epa.vic.gov.au/airwatch - This Community Information replaces the Community Information issued at 2:07 pm on Sunday 5 May. There is no immediate threat to the community and no action is required.
